description: Borrowed from Angloromani pal (“brother, friend”), from Romani phral (“brother”), from Sanskrit भ्रातृ (bhrātṛ, “brother”). Doublet of brother and frater.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) A friend, buddy, mate, cobber; someone to hang around with.
examples: Little Timmy's out playing with his pals.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) An informal term of address, often used ironically in a hostile way.
examples: Don't you threaten me, pal – I'll report you to the police.

verbs.description: pal (third-person singular simple present pals, present participle palling, simple past and past participle palled)

entries.meaning: (slang) Be friends with, hang around with.
examples: John plans to pal around with Joe today.
